paper_id: Release Kinetics of Nonexchangeable Potassium by Different Extractants from Soils of Varying Mineralogy and Depth

paper_metadata.title: Release Kinetics of Nonexchangeable Potassium by Different Extractants from Soils of Varying Mineralogy and Depth
paper_metadata.journal: Communications In Soil Science and Plant Analysis
paper_metadata.research_focus: Investigation of nonexchangeable potassium (K) release kinetics from major benchmark soil series of India as affected by mineralogy of clay and silt fractions, soil depth, and extraction media.
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: Understanding the dynamics and availability of nonexchangeable K, which is a significant proportion of plant K needs, especially under intensive cropping, and evaluating factors influencing its release rates.

research_context.study_objectives: 1) To evaluate the nonexchangeable K release from important benchmark soils varying in mineralogy, K status, and also in relation to soil depth and extraction media; 2) to evaluate different mathematical models for describing nonexchangeable K release and to find whether their performance varies with mineralogical composition of soils, soil K status, and extraction media; and 3) to examine the relationship of K release rates obtained in the kinetic studies with conventional soil test measures of K.
research_context.soil_k_research_role: The study is entirely focused on soil potassium, specifically the release kinetics of its nonexchangeable fraction, which is crucial for plant nutrition.
research_context.geographic_setting: Six major benchmark soil series of India, occurring widely in intensively cultivated regions across six states: Kamliakheri (Indore, Madhya Pradesh), Noyyal (Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu), Lukhi (Gurgaon, Haryana), Rarha (Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh), Kodad (Nalgonda, Andhra Pradesh), and Vijayapura (Bangalore, Karnataka).
research_context.environmental_conditions: Soils varied in pH (acidic to alkaline), CaCO3 content, organic carbon, CEC, and dominant clay mineralogy (smectitic, illitic, kaolinitic).
research_context.agricultural_context: The study is motivated by the significant contribution of nonexchangeable K to plant K nutrition (up to 90-95% of total plant K uptake under intensive cropping) and the reported lack of crop responses to applied K even in soils with low exchangeable K. Subsoil K contribution is also highlighted as substantial for crop nutrition.
research_context.study_design: Laboratory kinetic study using Ca-saturated soil samples. Nonexchangeable K release was measured over time using different chemical extractants. Mathematical models were applied to describe the release kinetics.
research_context.temporal_scope: Kinetic study conducted over 427 hours (approx. 17.8 days) with 20 discrete sampling points (1, 7, 19, 43, 67, 95, 115, 139, 163, 187, 211, 235, 259, 283, 307, 331, 355, 379, 403, and 427 hours).
research_context.spatial_scope: Six benchmark soil series, representing varying mineralogy and K status. Samples collected from two depths: surface (0–15 cm) and subsurface (15–30 cm). Duplicate samples were used for kinetic studies.

concentration_measurements.sample_context: Surface soils (0-15 cm) of six benchmark series
concentration_measurements.spatial_context: Kamliakheri, Noyyal, Lukhi, Rarha, Kodad, Vijayapura series

concentration_measurements.sample_context: Surface soils (0-15 cm) of six benchmark series
concentration_measurements.spatial_context: Kamliakheri, Noyyal, Lukhi, Rarha, Kodad, Vijayapura series

concentration_measurements.sample_context: Surface soils (0-15 cm) of six benchmark series
concentration_measurements.spatial_context: Kamliakheri, Noyyal, Lukhi, Rarha, Kodad, Vijayapura series

pool_characterizations.analytical_method: Successive extractions with 0.01 M CaCl2, 0.01 M citric acid, and 0.01 M HCl over 427 hours

treatment_effects.mineralogy: Greater in smectitic soils (353 mg K kg-1 at 0-15 cm, 296 mg K kg-1 at 15-30 cm) than illitic (151 mg K kg-1 at 0-15 cm, 112 mg K kg-1 at 15-30 cm) and kaolinitic (194 mg K kg-1 at 0-15 cm, 167 mg K kg-1 at 15-30 cm) soils (averaged for 2 soils and 3 extractants).
treatment_effects.soil_depth: Larger in surface soils (0-15 cm) for smectitic and illitic soils; larger in subsurface soils (15-30 cm) for kaolinitic soils.
treatment_effects.extractant: 0.01 M citric acid extracted larger amounts, followed by 0.01 M CaCl2 and 0.01 M HCl.

pool_characterizations.analytical_method: Successive extractions with 0.01 M CaCl2, 0.01 M citric acid, and 0.01 M HCl over 427 hours

treatment_effects.soil_series: Noyyal series showed three- to four-fold higher release than Kamliakheri series.
treatment_effects.depth_and_extractant: Kamliakheri (0-15 cm): 165 (CaCl2), 152 (citric acid), 142 (HCl); Kamliakheri (15-30 cm): 131 (CaCl2), 135 (citric acid), 120 (HCl); Noyyal (0-15 cm): 518 (CaCl2), 668 (citric acid), 473 (HCl); Noyyal (15-30 cm): 392 (CaCl2), 616 (citric acid), 380 (HCl).

pool_characterizations.analytical_method: Successive extractions with 0.01 M CaCl2, 0.01 M citric acid, and 0.01 M HCl over 427 hours

treatment_effects.soil_series: Rarha series showed higher K release than Lukhi series.
treatment_effects.depth_and_extractant: Lukhi (0-15 cm): 105 (CaCl2), 163 (citric acid), 94 (HCl); Lukhi (15-30 cm): 84 (CaCl2), 135 (citric acid), 77 (HCl); Rarha (0-15 cm): 138 (CaCl2), 289 (citric acid), 118 (HCl); Rarha (15-30 cm): 97 (CaCl2), 195 (citric acid), 82 (HCl).

pool_characterizations.analytical_method: Successive extractions with 0.01 M CaCl2, 0.01 M citric acid, and 0.01 M HCl over 427 hours

treatment_effects.soil_series: Kodad series showed larger K release than Vijayapura series.
treatment_effects.depth_and_extractant: Kodad (0-15 cm): 101 (CaCl2), 126 (citric acid), 72 (HCl); Kodad (15-30 cm): 102 (CaCl2), 165 (citric acid), 117 (HCl); Vijayapura (0-15 cm): 66 (CaCl2), 71 (citric acid), 35 (HCl); Vijayapura (15-30 cm): 62 (CaCl2), 80 (citric acid), 39 (HCl).

process_rates.process: Nonexchangeable K release rate constant (First-order equation)
process_rates.measurement_approach: Calculated from first-order kinetic model (ln(K0-Kt) = a - bt)
process_rates.environmental_conditions: 25°C, Ca-saturated soils, varying mineralogy and depth

process_rates.process: Nonexchangeable K release rate constant (Parabolic diffusion equation)
process_rates.measurement_approach: Calculated from parabolic diffusion kinetic model (Kt/K0 = a + bt^(1/2))
process_rates.environmental_conditions: 25°C, Ca-saturated soils, varying mineralogy and depth

event_responses.soil_k_response: Rapid initial release followed by a slower, continuing process.
event_responses.response_timing: 20–50% of K release occurred within the first 7 hours of extraction. The amount of K extracted was greater in the first 3–4 extractions, decreased in later extractions, and then remained nearly constant after 10–11 extractions.
event_responses.recovery_pattern: Not applicable, as this was a continuous extraction study.

within_site_variability.variability_description: Surface soils (0–15 cm) showed larger cumulative K release in smectitic and illitic soils than subsurface (15–30 cm) soils. In kaolinitic soils, surface soils showed either the same or lower K release than subsurface soils.
controlling_factors: Downward movement of finer particles with leaching (in kaolinitic soils)

between_site_differences.site_comparison: Smectitic soils (mean 353 mg K kg-1 at 0-15 cm, 296 mg K kg-1 at 15-30 cm) exhibited greater release than illitic (mean 151 mg K kg-1 at 0-15 cm, 112 mg K kg-1 at 15-30 cm) and kaolinitic (mean 194 mg K kg-1 at 0-15 cm, 167 mg K kg-1 at 15-30 cm) soils (averaged for 2 soils and 3 extractants).
explanatory_factors: Clay mineralogy (smectite, illite, kaolinite, vermiculite, chlorite)
Presence of K-rich minerals (illite) in silt and clay fractions

between_site_differences.site_comparison: Larger values for smectitic soils (mean 91.13-101.55 x 10^-4 h^-1) followed by illitic (mean 81.02-91.38 x 10^-4 h^-1) and kaolinitic soils (mean 63.81-81.26 x 10^-4 h^-1).
explanatory_factors: Larger wedge zones and swelling nature of smectitic clay facilitating easier exchange
Tightly held K in illitic soils leading to slower exchange

between_site_differences.site_comparison: Smectitic soils showed lower release rate constants (mean 28.03-36.08 x 10^-3 h^-1) than illitic (mean 28.84-41.25 x 10^-3 h^-1) and kaolinitic soils (mean 27.30-40.78 x 10^-3 h^-1).
explanatory_factors: Diffusion gradient between interlayer (source) and exchange surfaces (sink)
Lower exchangeable K on clay surface and larger interlayer K in illite clay structure resulting in larger diffusion gradients in illitic soils
Higher clay content in smectitic soils

cycling_processes.description: Transfer of K from less available (interlayer of 2:1 clay minerals like micas and vermiculite) to more available soil pools (solution/exchangeable).
controlling_factors: Mineralogy of clay and silt fractions (smectite, illite, kaolinite, vermiculite, chlorite, feldspar, quartz)
Diffusion gradients between interlayer and exchange surfaces
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Successive extractions with dilute salt solutions (CaCl2), organic acids (citric acid), and strong acids (HCl) over time, followed by K measurement in supernatant.

plant_soil_interactions.interaction_type: K supply to plants from nonexchangeable pool
plant_soil_interactions.description: A significant proportion of plant K needs are met from the nonexchangeable fraction, especially under intensive cropping when exchangeable K reaches a minimal level. Nonexchangeable K can account for up to 90-95% of total plant K uptake.
plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Initially, exchangeable K contributes; with further cropping, nonexchangeable K becomes the primary source.
influencing_factors: Soil mineralogy and K release rates
Subsoil K availability (especially for deep-rooted crops)

chemical_processes.process: K exchange/release by dilute salt solutions (CaCl2)
chemical_processes.characterization: K+ ions on the surface of mineral structure are exchanged by Ca2+ in the CaCl2 solution. Due to larger size and hydration energy of Ca2+, it does not exchange easily with K further in the interlayer.
environmental_controls: Size of hydrated Ca2+ vs. K+
chemical_processes.implications: Lower K release rate constants compared to citric acid.

chemical_processes.process: K exchange/release by organic acids (citric acid)
chemical_processes.characterization: Larger amount of K released due to dissociated H+ ions and complexing organic ligands. Low molecular weight organic acids with OH and COOH groups form metal-organic complexes, accelerating mineral decomposition.
environmental_controls: Presence of OH and COOH groups in organic acids
chemical_processes.implications: Greater K mobilization, especially in later stages of release; higher release rate constants.

chemical_processes.characterization: Mechanism restricted to exchange of H+ ions with K+ ions of minerals. Once exchange positions are filled with H+, further exchange from highly selective sites is difficult with dilute acid solutions.
chemical_processes.implications: Lower K release compared to citric acid.

chemical_processes.characterization: The rate-limiting step is the diffusion of K ions from the interior of the particle to the surface, as assumed by the parabolic diffusion model. This is particularly relevant for illitic soils where interlayer space is more closed.
environmental_controls: Diffusion gradient between interlayer (source) and exchange surfaces (sink)
Clay structure (e.g., interlayer space in illite)
chemical_processes.implications: Better fit of parabolic diffusion equation for illitic soils.

chemical_processes.process: Film diffusion or exchange reaction controlled K release
chemical_processes.characterization: The rate-limiting step is either film diffusion or exchange reaction, particularly for smectitic soils due to their swelling nature.
environmental_controls: Accessibility of K sites (external planar surfaces, peripheral edge sites)
chemical_processes.implications: Better fit of first-order equation for smectitic soils.

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Different chemical extractants for nonexchangeable K

soil_k_effects.cumulative_release: 0.01 M citric acid extracted a larger amount of nonexchangeable K, followed by 0.01 M CaCl2 and 0.01 M HCl.
soil_k_effects.efficiency_by_soil_type: Efficiency of citric acid was greater in illitic soils (20-43% increase over CaCl2) than in smectitic (85-81% increase) and kaolinitic (19-50% increase) soils.
soil_k_effects.release_rate_constants: 0.01 M citric acid medium showed greater release rate constants (first-order) followed by 0.01 M CaCl2 and 0.01 M HCl for all soils.

mechanisms: Citric acid: Dissociated H+ ions and complexing organic ligands accelerating mineral decomposition.
HCl: Proton exchange with K+ ions, limited by saturation of exchange positions.
CaCl2: Ca2+ exchange with K+ ions, limited by larger size and hydration energy of Ca2+.

comparative_analysis.comparison_type: Comparison of extractant efficiency across soil mineralogy
comparative_analysis.statistical_significance: Implied by reported differences, though specific p-values not given for these comparisons.

analytical_methods.procedure_description: Measured in a 1:2.5 (w/v) soil to water mixture.
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Glass pH electrode (Elico pH analyzer model LI-612).

target_parameters: Mineralogical composition of silt and clay fractions
analytical_methods.procedure_description: Soils dispersed in 1% sodium hexametaphosphate. Sand separated by wet-sieving, silt by sedimentation, clay by siphoning. Mg-saturated silt and clay samples X-rayed, glycolated, and X-rayed again. K-saturated silt and clay samples X-rayed after drying (1h) and heating to 500°C (1h). Semiquantitative analysis based on peak area.
Measured in the supernatant liquid after centrifugation of soil suspensions.
Nonexchangeable K released with time was fitted using first-order, parabolic diffusion, zero-order, and Elovich equations. Least-square regression analysis was used.
quality_control: Standard error of the estimate (SE) calculated as SE = [(Σ(q - q')^2) / (n - 2)]^(1/2).

sampling_design.spatial_sampling: Six benchmark soil series from different regions of India. Samples collected from surface (0–15 cm) and subsurface (15–30 cm) depths.
sampling_design.temporal_sampling: For kinetic studies, K was measured at 20 time points over 427 hours.
sampling_design.sample_processing: Soils were air-dried and sieved. For kinetic studies, native exchangeable K was removed by Ca-saturation (equilibrating 5g soil with 0.25 M CaCl2 three times, washing with absolute alcohol and deionized water until Cl-free), then oven-dried at 60°C.
sampling_design.storage_handling: Not explicitly detailed beyond initial collection and processing.
sampling_design.representativeness: Benchmark soil series were chosen to represent a wide area varying in mineralogy and K status in intensively cultivated regions.

precision_measures: Standard error of the estimate (SE) for kinetic models (e.g., 0.02-0.05 for parabolic diffusion in CaCl2, 0.21-0.37 for first-order in CaCl2).
method_comparisons: Comparison of suitability of four kinetic models (first-order, parabolic diffusion, zero-order, Elovich) based on coefficient of determination (r^2) and SE values. Parabolic diffusion and first-order models performed best.

climate_conditions.precipitation: Not specified, but 'dryland agriculture' mentioned for one institute.

soil_properties.classification: Vertisol (Kamliakheri), Vertic Ustochrept (Kamliakheri), Ustothermic Chromustert (Noyyal), Udic Ustochrept (Lukhi, Rarha), Typic Paleustalf (Kodad), Oxic Haplustalf (Vijayapura).
soil_properties.texture: Fine textured (smectitic soils), light textured (kaolinitic soils).
soil_properties.mineralogy: Smectite dominant (Kamliakheri, Noyyal), Illite dominant (Lukhi, Rarha), Kaolinite dominant (Kodad, Vijayapura). Also mentions vermiculite, chlorite, amorphous materials (hydrous oxides of Fe, Al, Mn, hydrated silico-aluminas), feldspar, and quartz.
soil_properties.organic_matter: Organic Carbon content (g kg-1): Kamliakheri 4.8, Noyyal 6.9, Lukhi 3.8, Rarha 3.1, Kodad 4.2, Vijayapura 4.0.

chemical_properties.pH: Range 5.7-8.4 (Kamliakheri 7.8, Noyyal 8.4, Lukhi 8.4, Rarha 8.2, Kodad 6.0, Vijayapura 5.7).
chemical_properties.CaCO3: Range 11-65 g kg-1 (Kamliakheri 65, Noyyal 52, Lukhi 29, Rarha 24, Kodad 19, Vijayapura 11).
chemical_properties.CEC: Range 5.8-39.8 Cmol(+) kg-1 (Kamliakheri 39.8, Noyyal 34, Lukhi 5.8, Rarha 7.1, Kodad 8.9, Vijayapura 6.3).

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: The study examined the relationship between K release rates from kinetic studies and conventional soil test measures of K (e.g., NaTPB-K). Correlation coefficients between NaTPB-K and cumulative K release were lower (r^2 = 0.58–0.72) for all soils, but improved substantially (r^2 = 0.94–0.95) when illitic soils were excluded. A positive and highly significant correlation (r^2 = 0.94) was found between NaTPB-K and intercept values of the first-order equation.
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: The research is directly relevant to plant K nutrition, emphasizing that nonexchangeable K is a major source for plants, especially under intensive cropping. It highlights the importance of subsoil K for deep-rooted crops and explains why crops might not respond to K fertilization even with low exchangeable K if nonexchangeable K release is sufficient.
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: Aims to provide information for assessing K fertilizer needs by considering nonexchangeable K release, particularly in mineralogically diverse soils.
research_integration.comparative_context: Compares findings with previous studies on K release kinetics in various soils (e.g., Kalmia and Kennansville soils of the United States, Indian soils) and using different models and extractants, citing numerous references.
research_integration.literature_positioning: Builds upon established knowledge that nonexchangeable K is a significant source for plants and investigates the kinetics of its release, which is a less understood aspect compared to static K forms.

methodological_constraints: The study is a laboratory kinetic study, which may not fully replicate complex field conditions.

The correlation between soil test nonexchangeable K (NaTPB-K) and cumulative K release was found to be lower for illitic soils, suggesting that NaTPB-K alone might not be a sufficient predictor for K release in these specific soil types.
interpretation_caveats: Illite-rich alluvial soils, despite high nonexchangeable K status, may suffer from K deficiency under intensive cropping if the rate of K release from nonexchangeable to exchangeable/solution phase is insufficient to meet plant K uptake.

extraction_assessment.extraction_notes: The paper provided a wealth of specific quantitative data, especially in the abstract and results sections, which allowed for detailed population of the quantitative_soil_k_data, temporal_patterns, and spatial_variations sections. Methodological details were also very well described. The paper's focus on kinetics and mineralogy allowed for strong characterization of processes and mechanisms. The 'TABLE DATA' was empty in the prompt, but the paper text itself contained tables (Table 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) which were crucial for extraction. I extracted data from the text descriptions of these tables.

_usage_metadata.paper_id: Release Kinetics of Nonexchangeable Potassium by Different Extractants from Soils of Varying Mineralogy and Depth
